name: Intro to Machine Translation
L95zy: Reading ability in a language other than English
xq1Dp: Python proficiency, CS 474 or CS 472 or Ling 581 or similar exposure to MT or NLP technologies
mXQpZ:
Machine Translation (MT) is widely recognized as one of the most representative applications of AI and ML technologies. It has long been considered one of the “Holy Grails” of Natural Language Processing, with the first research projects starting in the early 1950’s. Today, with the advent of neural MT (NMT), research, development, and production use of MT has skyrocketed. Companies like Google, Microsoft, Meta, and Amazon machine translate hundreds of billions of words every day. With the integration of neural speech-to-text and text-to-speech technology, applications of speech-to-speech MT, such as automatic video dubbing, have also exploded in just the past two years. A 2022 report on the growth of the MT industry shows that there are now over 45 provider companies of MT, furnishing MT between 125,000 unique language pairs. The Church is also now finally riding this wave of MT technology, fulfilling President Kimball’s prophetic vision of technology enabling the gospel to go to all the world. In his second century address, he specifically called out the importance of BYU’s participation in the development of computer-assisted translation.


This course will particularly target CS students fluent in 2 or more languages, including female and male RMs and ethnically diverse students. It prepares students for advanced work in this field, whether in MS or PhD programs, or in the increasingly plentiful industry R&D job openings. Steve Richardson has taught this course 3 times with 8, 10, and 6 students, respectively - the lower number apparently resulting from the switch to fall semester from last winter semester.


Please note, this course is an elective in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

mXQpZ:
As part of our multi-year effort to update the CS curriculum, we are revising CS 240 and CS 340 so that students practice software design principles in the context of a web application instead of a mobile application. This is based on feedback from our employer advisory board that web applications are of primary importance and mobile applications have secondary importance.


To make this change for CS 340, we need to changes its prerequisites and learning outcomes.


The prerequisites for CS 340 are changing from CS 240 → CS 240 and CS 260. CS 260 covers introductory web programming, enabling CS 340 to build on these concepts rather than teaching them from scratch.


CS 260 is already taken by well over 90% of the students in our program, so this will not affect student time to graduation. CS 260 will now be required in our the general CS major and the Software Engineering emphasis -- see those proposals for details.


Please note, this course is an elective in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

description: This class combines designing the user experience with implementing the technology. Students learn website design, information architecture, and how to design for the broader ecosystem of use. Finally, students will learn principles specifically relevant to website design and information architecture. Web design is one of the most common UX jobs and so this makes their skills highly marketable.

learningOutcomes.name: Analyze the Context of a Design Problem
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will learn how to analyze secondary data related to their design problem in order to understand the context in which people are using a given technology. Namely, this class goes beyond just interviewing users and to analyzing multiple sources of data that helps them understand the context in which the users are using the technology. This could include analyzing bug report, comments on social media, Q&A forums, other documentation about the topic, interview transcripts from multiple sets of stakeholders (e.g., users v. non users).

mXQpZ:
The CS department has taught CS 356 as an introduction to human computer interaction for several years, and there is too much material to be covered in a singe class. As part of a new proposal to create a Computer Science major with an emphasis in Human Computer Interaction, we are splitting CS 356 into CS 256 and CS 356. The material in CS 256 is very similar to a class taught by Amanda Hughes in IT&C (Amanda joined are department at the start of Fall semester 2022).


CS 356 is being adjusted to build on these changes, including changes to the title and learning outcomes.


Please note, this course is required in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

mXQpZ:
​​The Computer Science department has developed a phased strategy for updating our curriculum. We are in the middle stages of this process. Currently we are proposing to adjust the prerequisites of some courses in the core to provide more flexibility for students.


As part of this change, we are modifying the prerequisite for CS 312 from CS 240 to (CS 236 and CS 260) or (CS 236 and CS 224) or (Math 290 and CS 235).


CS 312 has traditionally relied on material in CS 236, which has been transitively required by having a prerequisite of CS 240. Dropping CS 236 as a prerequisite for CS 240 requires us to change the prerequisite for CS 312 to list CS 236 rather than CS 240.


While we are making this change we re-assessed what material students need prior to CS 330. We found that they need (1) experience with discrete math or mathematical reasoning (CS 236 or Math 290) and (2) experience programming in more than one language. We feel the set of prerequisite options listed above will cover those two needs.


See the CS program proposal for details on how our prerequisite changes, collectively, will help reduce student time to graduation, while providing more flexibility for students in our major and in other majors as they explore Computer Science.


Please note, this course is an elective in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

description: Introduction to current topics in network science including network formation models, information flow over networks, and key network properties.

learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to implement and use Barabasi-Albert, Watts-Strogatz, Erdos-Renyi, and affiliation network-based algorithms.

Students will be able to implement and use graph theory concepts applicable to networks: adjacency matrix, adjacency matrix, adjacency lists, graph Laplacian, algebraic connectivity, spectral graph properties.
Students will implement and understand how information and disease spread/diffuse over a network: simple contagion and complex contagion/diffusion of innovations.
Students will apply graph metrics to understand diffusion dynamics: clustering, density, diameter, algebraic connectivity, degree distribution, distance, modularity, assortativity.
Students will be able to implement agent-based models over networks.
Students will be able to mitigate/promote network effects by identifying communities, removing edges, adding edges, choosing early adopters.

mXQpZ:
​​The Computer Science department has developed a phased strategy for updating our curriculum. We are in the middle stages of this process. Currently we are proposing to adjust the prerequisites of some courses in the core to provide more flexibility for students.


As part of this change, we are modifying the prerequisite for CS 312 from CS 240 to CS 236.


This need is caused by another change we are making -- modifying CS 240 to require just CS 235 (and not CS 236).


CS 312 has traditionally relied on material in CS 236, which has been transitively required by having a prerequisite of CS 240. Dropping CS 236 as a prerequisite for CS 240 requires us to change the prerequisite for CS 312 to list CS 236 rather than CS 240.


See the CS program proposal for details on how our prerequisite changes, collectively, will help reduce student time to graduation, while providing more flexibility for students in our major and in other majors as they explore Computer Science.


Please note, this course is required in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

mXQpZ:
This proposal updates the title, content, and objectives of CS 456 to make the class fit within the new HCI emphasis in CS and to modernize the content. The old version of the class focuses on system-level concepts such as widget implementation that have become less relevant as very few, if any, students will go on to write a new user interface toolkit from scratch.


The new CS 456 builds on core HCI classes in the new HCI emphasis to provide deep experience with the design and prototyping process in the context of mobile and ubiquitous HCI. The class includes unique aspects of mobile and ubiquitous HCI such as the importance of context and the presence of sensors. Students will complete a semester-long project in which they design, prototype, and evaluate a mobile interactive experience.


The new CS 456 course outcomes build on the HCI emphasis in CS program outcomes in methods, prototypes, and HCI theories.


We are also changing the prerequisite for CS 456 to list just CS 356 and not CS 240. This change reflects the prior experience students need coming into the course, and provides greater flexibility for students who want to take the class.


Please note, this course is required in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

mXQpZ:
This was part of our announced plan when we created CS 111 last year, and we have been coordinating this change with affected departments. The motivation for this change is that students need extra time practicing fundamental material (in labs and projects) so they can achieve mastery. The course includes 3 hours of lecture plus 2.5 hours of lab time. Students need sufficient extra hours for time to work on homework and projects, especially considering that debugging can take significant (and highly variable) time. A 4 credit course makes sufficient room for this practice time. A survey from the pilot we ran last year indicated that students spent a total of 12 hours per week on the class (including lecture and lab time).


We have surveyed top CS programs across the country – including Stanford, Berkeley, CMU, Princeton, and Washington – and nearly all use 4 credit courses in their early core. CS 111 is a true introduction to computer science (which we have previously lacked), including important topics such as functional programming, object-oriented programming, recursion, containers, trees, frames, ENBF, and interpreters. Students get a first exposure to concepts they will use (and get deeper exposure to) in CS 224, CS 235, and CS 236.


Increasing CS 111 to 4 credits will help students develop stronger fundamentals. This will allow more students to confidently take 2 or 3 CS courses at a time (as needed by the major) and thus graduate more quickly than they otherwise would. We also believe this may help reduce the failure rate in subsequent CS courses. We have found that the failing students tend to lack the fundamentals they need to succeed in the major, with some often repeating courses several times to try to make it through.


Affected departments have been working to adjust to this change over the past year and are either adjusting their majors or will be asking the university to accommodate a 1-credit increase in credits for their program. Programs that previously used only CS 142 as a requirement can substitute “CS 110 or CS 111” without any change in credits, since CS 110 is a 3-credit course. Programs that previously required both CS 142 and CS 235 can substitute CS 111 for CS 142 in their requirements.


The CS department advises students who have no prior programming experience to take CS 110 before CS 111. We work closely with students so that they can transfer from CS 111 down to CS 110 early in the semester if needed. We are planning to create a non-graded assessment that prospective CS 111 students can take to determine if they are ready for the course.


This course is also required by Bioinformatics, Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Mathematics (including ACME), and Physics (and Astronomy and Applied Physics). It is an option and an elective in various other programs.


Please note, this course is required in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

mXQpZ:
Blockchain technologies are being used in a wide range of applications, including cryptocurrency, distributed finance, smart contracts, and voting. An elective course in this area gives students the opportunity to develop a deep understanding of how these technologies work and experience building distributed applications. It is important for our students t be conversant in technologies that are in such wide use. Students taking the course will be prepared for job opportunities in everything related to the blockchain. Kent Seamons has taught this course for four years on a provisional basis, with enrollments of 30, 5, 17 and 29 students, indicating good interest in the course.

mXQpZ:
We are changing the name of these classes in order to clarify to students which classes are part of our animated film capstone and the order they should take them.


The structure of the program now enables students to put three semesters into the animated film project, if desired, and get credit for all three semesters.


Once they are renumbered there would be no need to have the R attached, since students will have a clear picture of what class to take first and when, so they will not need to repeat these courses. The computer Science department has always had a requirement where students complete 1 course, and the options have been either CSANM 450R or CSANM 459R (Video Game Production 1). However, the current Computer Science Animation and Games proposal is change the requirement to read, “complete 6 credits”. The choices would be the 3 Animation Film classes, CSANM 459 (Video Game Production1) and CSANM 460 (Video Game Production 2). It would not be advantageous for students to repeat these courses, and it would also delay time to graduation.

name: Visual Narrative
L95zy: Major status -Animation, or CS animation and Games Emphasis
xq1Dp: Acceptance into either the Computer Science or BFA Animation program
mXQpZ:
In Animation and Film the mantra “Story is King” is a well known phrase. As the animation curriculum has grown it has become prudent to isolate a class where we can teach knowledge specific to shot design and animated film structure. Here are our primary justifications.


1) All disciplines of animation connect to storytelling through how their work is presented in camera. As such, all need a practical understanding of story, cinematography, layout and shot design.


2) In the past we have paired this material with Storyboarding instruction. By separating the teaching of visual narrative from the drawing and performance skills specific to Storyboarding, we will improve the ability of students to absorb material that is critical to their success. A small number of our students go on to work as storyboard artists, while a much larger number still require these skills in daily production.


3) By introducing the class early on we will create a stronger sequence of instruction. Foundational narrative skills taught here will improve specific skill classes such as Storyboarding(DESAN 260), Visual Development (DESAN 361R) and Previsualization (CSANM 353). All aspects of shot production will benefit from a stronger understanding of visual story. Storyboarding (DESAN 260) and Previsualization (CSANM 353) classes will be able to focus on studio practices instead of foundational instruction. For more Design oriented students an understanding of the material will inform them how to design props and spaces for use in a shot based environment.


4) The separation of film structure and design from the mechanics of drafting and storyboarding make this class an excellent way for CS Animation Emphasis students to learn the necessary story & editing skills to be successful artists. In the past our CS students have had to pick up these skills during capstone classes. We would like for them to have an elective option to learn them earlier in the program.


This course will be required in the Animation BFA and an elective in the CS:Animation and Games emphasis.

mXQpZ:
As part of our multi-year effort to update the CS curriculum, we are revising CS 240 and CS 340 so that students practice software design principles in the context of a web application instead of a mobile application. This is based on feedback from our employer advisory board that web applications are of primary importance and mobile applications have secondary importance.


As we are making this change to CS 240 we are also updating its title, learning objectives, and prerequisites.


The title better reflects the content -- software construction. The learning objectives have long been out of date and we are updating them to reflect the content of the course.


We are changing the prerequisite to CS 235 (eliminating CS 236) to better reflect the preparation we expect from students entering the course. Previously we relied on CS 236 to give students additional experience with object-oriented programming. However, this creates a long prerequisite chain, and the discrete math content in CS 236 is not required for CS 240. With the introduction of CS 111, we believe students will be better prepared coming out of CS 235 than they were in the past. In addition, making this change will provide students with more flexibility as they take our major or minor, and will better serve the programs that require CS 240 by removing a prerequisite that is not needed. This may be particularly helpful for students majoring in Bioinformatics. This also enables CS 236 to adapt independently of CS 240 in the future and allows us to be more flexible with the CS minor in the future.


The instructors will be managing the course carefully to ensure that students are able to succeed. They will also be communicating with the instructors of CS 111 and CS 235 to be sure students are adequately prepared.


From a content perspective, we will be eliminating most of the front-end/Android material to make room for deeper coverage of software engineering concepts and principles while keeping the course accessible to other departments that rely on it.


Please note, this course is required in the new HCI emphasis but we don't have a program code for it yet.

mXQpZ:
We are changing the name of these classes in order to clarify to students which classes are part of our animated film capstone and the order they should take them.


The structure of the program now enables students to put three semesters into the animated film project, if desired, and get credit for all three semesters.


Once they are renamed there will be no need to have the R attached, since students will have a clear picture of what class to take first and when, so they will not have any need to repeat these courses. The computer Science department has always had a requirement where students complete 1 course, and the options have been either CSANM 450R or CSANM 459R (Video Game Production 1). However, the current Computer Science Animation and Games proposal is to change the requirement to read, “complete 6 credits”. The choices would be the 3 Animation Film classes, CSANM 459 (Video Game Production1) and CSANM 460 (Video Game Production 2). It would not be advantageous for students to repeat these courses, and it would also delay time to graduation.

mXQpZ:
Request:

Change the title of Math 522 to "Mathematical Foundations of Deep Learning".
Change the prerequisites for Math 522 to Math 213, Math 215, and Math 314. C S 111 or equivalent. Math 402 or 431 or equivalent. (But leave these prerequisites unenforced.)

Justification:

The proposed title more specifically identifies the content that Math 521 has had over the last 3 years. Rather than being a miscellaneous topics course, it has focused on the mathematical concept of deep learning.
It no longer seems best to require Math 522 students to have previously taken Math 521. The proposed prerequisites ensure that students have had basic college-level exposure to linear algebra, probability, multivariable calculus, and Python programming.
By not enforcing the prerequisites, we will facilitate enrollment by incoming graduate students who may have done their undergraduate work somewhere other than BYU.
